newsitem.title: USA: Aetna, HMO peers bruised by Q2 earnings.
newsitem.headline: Aetna, HMO peers bruised by Q2 earnings.

text.p: Disappointing second-quarter earnings by Aetna Inc's Aetna U.S. Healthcare unit sharply depressed the company's shares Tuesday, causing jitters and profit taking in Oxford Health Plans and United HealthCare Corp.
Aetna, whose shares did not begin trading until almost two hours after the New York Stock Exhange opened, were off 12-13/16 to 104/3/16 in early afternoon trade.

Aetna shares were also bruised by a downgrade from Smith Barney, which cut its rating on the company to outperform from buy, citing disappointment with its managed-care performance in the 1997 second quarter.
Oxford was off 3-15/16 to 81-7/8 despite its release earlier Tuesday of second quarter earnings of $0.45 per share, one cent higher than the First Call consensus analysts' estimate.
"Apparently the Aetna downgrade was disappointing to investors and Oxford fell off in sympathy," said PaineWebber health care analyst David Lothson.

"Smith Barney has been extremely bullish on these (managed health care) stocks for a long time, so when they downgrade a company, people get real nervous they're going to downgrade others," Lothson said.
Smith Barney expressed concern that Aetna's medical loss ratio increased one percent sequentially from 82.6 percent in the 1997 first quarter to 83.6 percent in the second quarter.
The ratio is a measure of the portion of premium revenues paid out to cover medical costs of members.
And, Smith Barney cited a sequential decrease in Aetna's Health Risk business, where operating earnings slipped from $198 million in the 1997 first quarter to $172 million in the second quarter.

The business segment includes products in which Aetna assumes all or a majority of health care cost and utilization risk. Aetna said higher premium rates were more than offset by increases in commercial and Medicare HMO medical costs.
Lothson said concerns about HMO profitability in the wake of the Aetna earnings report apparently pinched shares of United HealthCare Corp, which was off 1-13/16 to 57-15/16.

Lothson said he was maintaining his neutral rating on the HMO group. "There's too much excess underwriting capacity out there to promote much pricing flexibility. And earnings in that environment are at risk," he said.
Gary Frazier, a Bear, Stearns managing director, said the market seemed quite concerned about the "slight uptick" in Aetna's Medicare costs.
"So a lot of HMOs that have exposure to the Medicare side of the business are selling off, including Oxford, which is building its Medicare business," Frazier said.
Frazier said the market apparently was also concerned by Oxford's announcement Tuesday that founder Stephen Wiggins would be relinquishing his CEO, although remaining active as company chairman.
"I don't think anything has changed in terms of Stephen Wiggins' day-to-day responsibilities. You'll continue to see his strong imprint going forward," Frazier predicted.
